verses.text: Then I heard a loud voice from the temple saying to the seven angels, 'Go, pour out the seven bowls of God's wrath on the earth.'
verses.comment: The 'loud voice from the temple' signifies authority from God Himself. The bowls are symbols for the fullness and completeness of divine judgment, reminiscent of the Old Testament plagues. The temple reference indicates the action is commanded directly by God, drawing parallels to His direct intervention in history (see Lev. 26:21).

verses.text: So the first angel went and poured out his bowl on the land, and foul and painful sores came upon the people who had the mark of the beast and who worshiped its image.
verses.comment: This plague is similar to the sixth plague of Egypt (Ex. 9:10-11). The sores afflict only those with the mark of the beast, emphasizing that allegiance to evil brings consequences. Notice the sacramental imagery of a ‘mark’—a sign of belonging, which will be echoed and contrasted with the seal of the faithful elsewhere in Revelation.

verses.text: The second angel poured out his bowl into the sea, and it became like the blood of a dead man, and every living creature in the sea died.
verses.comment: This bowl echoes the first plague in Egypt, where water turns to blood (Ex. 7:20-21). The pervasive death in the sea signifies the severe consequences of sin spreading through all creation.

verses.text: The third angel poured out his bowl into the rivers and the springs of water, and they became blood.
verses.comment: Rivers and springs—sources of life—are corrupted, reflecting how sin reaches every part of the world. This points to God’s total sovereignty, and the pattern follows the Old Testament plagues.

verses.text: And I heard the angel of the waters say, 'You are just, O Holy One, who is and who was, because you have judged these things.'
verses.comment: The angel’s proclamation affirms God’s justice and holiness. The phrase 'who is and who was' highlights God’s eternal nature and faithfulness. This shows that divine judgment is always righteous.

verses.text: For they have shed the blood of saints and prophets, and you have given them blood to drink. They deserve it.
verses.comment: This shows the principle of retribution: those who persecute the faithful receive justice proportionate to their deeds (Matt. 23:35). The theme of martyrdom of the saints is important and recurring.

verses.text: And I heard the altar respond, 'Yes, Lord God Almighty, true and just are your judgments.'
verses.comment: The altar represents the prayers of the saints (Rev. 6:9). The affirmation of God's justice reiterates the trustworthiness and righteousness of His ways.

verses.text: The fourth angel poured out his bowl on the sun, and it was allowed to scorch people with fire.
verses.comment: The sun, usually a source of life, becomes a means of judgment. Physical suffering results from divine wrath—a reversal of blessings, alluding to both spiritual and literal consequences of rebellion.

verses.text: People were scorched by the intense heat, and they cursed the name of God who had power over these plagues. They did not repent or give him glory.
verses.comment: Despite the suffering, hearts remain hardened, echoing Pharaoh's response to the plagues (Ex. 9:34). This underlines the importance of repentance—a foundational response to God's discipline.

verses.text: The fifth angel poured out his bowl on the throne of the beast, and its kingdom was plunged into darkness. People gnawed their tongues in agony
verses.comment: The darkness recalls the ninth Egyptian plague (Ex. 10:21-23). The throne of the beast identifies a spiritual and political center of evil, which faces divine punishment.

verses.text: and blasphemed the God of heaven because of their suffering and their sores, and they did not repent of their deeds.
verses.comment: Even under judgment, there is no repentance. Sin’s grip presents a spiritual blindness which only divine grace can heal.

verses.text: The sixth angel poured out his bowl on the great river Euphrates, and its water was dried up to prepare the way for the kings from the east.
verses.comment: The drying of the Euphrates symbolizes the removal of barriers for invading armies. This event recalls God's control over the nations, as seen in Israel’s Exodus (crossing the Red Sea) and the return from exile (Isa. 11:15-16).

verses.text: And I saw three unclean spirits like frogs coming out of the mouth of the dragon, out of the mouth of the beast, and out of the mouth of the false prophet.
verses.comment: Frogs remind of the plague upon Egypt (Ex. 8:2-6), representing impurity. The three evil figures (dragon, beast, false prophet) echo false trinity opposed to God. Their unity highlights the force of evil opposition against God's people.

verses.text: For they are spirits of demons performing signs, who go out to the kings of the whole world, to gather them for battle on the great day of God the Almighty.
verses.comment: Miraculous signs by evil spirits lead nations into opposition to God. The reference to the ‘great day’ is echoed in prophetic warnings (see Matt. 24:24).

verses.text: Behold, I am coming like a thief! Blessed is he who stays awake and keeps his clothes, so that he may not go about naked and be exposed to shame.
verses.comment: Christ's return is sudden and unexpected (Matt. 24:43). 'Clothes' symbolize righteousness and readiness. The imagery of shame and nakedness calls for vigilance and perseverance in holiness, a theme echoed by the early church.

verses.text: And they gathered them together to the place that in Hebrew is called Armageddon.
verses.comment: Armageddon references the traditional site of great battles in Israel. It symbolizes the final confrontation between the forces of good and evil. The spiritual meaning points to the ultimate triumph of God's reign.

verses.text: The seventh angel poured out his bowl into the air, and a loud voice came out of the temple from the throne, saying, 'It is done!'
verses.comment: The seventh bowl completes God’s judgment. The cry ‘It is done!’ echoes Christ’s words on the cross (John 19:30), signaling the completion of redemption and the fullness of divine justice.

verses.text: And there were flashes of lightning, rumblings, peals of thunder, and a great earthquake such as had never been since man was on the earth, so great was that earthquake.
verses.comment: The dramatic signs recall theophanies at Sinai (Ex. 19:16-18), marking God’s direct intervention in human history. Earthquakes symbolize divine judgment and decisive change.

verses.text: The great city was split into three parts, and the cities of the nations fell; and God remembered Babylon the great, to give her the cup of the wine of his fierce wrath.
verses.comment: Babylon symbolizes the fullness of human rebellion and sin. God’s remembrance is not forgetting, but intentional judgment upon evil. The cup is a powerful biblical image for divine wrath (see Isa. 13:19).

verses.text: And every island fled away, and no mountains were to be found.
verses.comment: Creation itself is shaken. The cosmic upheaval is a sign of the end of the old order and the beginning of God’s renewed kingdom.

verses.text: And great hailstones, about one hundred pounds each, came down from heaven on people; and they cursed God because of the plague of hail, for the plague was so severe.
verses.comment: Hail recalls the seventh plague of Egypt (Ex. 9:22-26). Even these signs do not bring repentance, underscoring the stubbornness of sinners and the perfect consistency of God's justice. The need for intercession and mediated grace is implied—hinting at the ongoing ministry of the Church in the world.
